transcription.text: Welcome everyone to the Ethereum 2.0 client panel discussion. The idea with this is to,
well, after this morning's presentations where we saw lots of the work that's been done and
been given insight into some of the solutions that have come up with to explore more how
we move on from here, in particular, how do we do that together? There's a lot of togetherness,
I think in general, in Ethereum 2.0, there's many of the design aspects have been centered around
trying to coordinate people, be that through the use of technologies that other people are using
was on the P2P, BLS standardization, etc. to the multi-clinted approach we're taking.
And I think that's a really powerful thing as we've seen.
And so I think a good place to start off with is something we had quite recently,
which was the Interop event. This was a great opportunity where we locked, well,
basically locked a bunch of people in a room to see what happened. And the results of this
experiment was we got seven clients speaking to each other, which is pretty, pretty, freaking
incredible. And yeah, so another we've achieved that, I think that's allowed us to get a lot
further along this route. So I think you should have some introductions before we quickly dive into
this. So if you can start down that side and have everyone just say the name, who they're
working on and what was the sort of one thing that they took from Interop or what's the one,
maybe the main thing that you guys are now working on as a result of Interop.
Hey, I'm Ben, I'm just standing in for the great Jodalong on this panel. I kind of assembled the
Artemis team a year ago. I'm best better known for what's new in ETH2 these days. I was at Interop
and it was awesome. Takeaways, I think it's time to press on to production now. We've proved the
concept. It works. We can inter operate. It's very cool, but now we're moving into new phase with
Artemis and handing it over to the production team to do all the stuff, like writing documentation and
searching the comments for to do and all that good stuff.
Everyone, I'm Ro from Prismatic Labs. I was unfortunately not at Interop, but remotely helping
out teams there and figuring out how to get people on board Prism. One of the biggest takeaways was
getting everyone to easily run a beacon chain and a validator. We had to make it easy for everyone
and they didn't prove a lot of our local development a lot. I made it very, very easy to launch a
beacon chain with n number of deterministic validators. That sort of standardization that
came out of the effort made our lives easier and hopefully others lives easier.
Hi, everyone. I'm Alex Stokes. I work on Trinity, which is the Python implementation of ETH2.
Yeah, Interop was great, as we'll probably all tell you here. The biggest thing I think we
probably all saw across the board was, yeah, just having these sort of coordinated starts and
getting these test nets to actually all go at the same time. We have a large number of clients,
and so we have some extra fun just wrangling all these cats. There's a bunch of little stuff
that we saw specific to Trinity from the Interop. The big thing there will probably be focusing on
longer term over the next, I don't know, let's say, three to six months is heavy focus on performance.
Like I said, we're a Python client, so we kind of have a performance penalty. We incur de facto,
so we'll be doing a lot of optimization there. We were looking at dropping our really sort of
tight loops and things into Rust. So we've had some work on Lightrust modules in Python, which is fun.
And yeah, that's about it. Hello everyone, my name is Paul. I work on Lighthouse. It's one of
the Rust implementations. I think one of the great things that came from Interop was just a lot of
scripts that we can use to build each other. So, yeah, it's like, built a bunch of scripts,
which was great. So now we have a bunch of tools that we can use by ourselves to test with other
clients. So that really helps reduce the friction that we can, before we can test our client against
others. Well, we're working on now. After Interop, we're basically targeting feature completeness.
We have an RFP for security review out there, so we're preparing for that. And we're working on
trying to take our client into the tens of thousands of validator ranges and above to make sure
that we can run nice and quickly and efficiently with production level numbers of validators.
I'm Zhaori from the Nimbus team. A lesson that we learned from Interop, I guess, is the
importance of testing. Our success was largely due to the very well-prepared test suit and
where there were bumps along the road. These are places where the tests are kind of missing.
I would repeat what Pozzo posted that one of the most valuable takeaways was these scripts
that allow us now to run multi-client test nets. And I think we should all keep improving on them.
Regarding the future of Nimbus client, we'll be publishing very shortly our roadmap for getting
Nimbus production ready. And we hope to do that in the next six months.
Hi, I'm Dejun from runtime verification. So we developed a K kind of client, but we are not
really just running the client, but just formally verifying the client.
But I hope there's some crazy ideal, crazy users use our K client as just adding another
diversity. But yeah, so far we just fall verification purpose.
My name is Michael. I'm from Harmony team. The Interop went very well. And I even didn't expect
it. It was so productive. As a follow-ups, we are continuing to work on a fork choice test,
like a complex test. Also, we need to finish sync and was thinking about
start working on BLS stuff, finishing discovery. And the main takeaway from Interop is that we
are merging efforts with our chemists. So we probably can avoid this production ready stuff. So yeah.
Okay, that's it. I'm away from party. So I think we didn't join the Interop on site, but I was
doing some similar Interop stuff at home. Trying to get it work, put them all nice. It mostly works.
I think the most important license we learned is still testing. So we were one or two patch version
behind. But even except that we still have like one or two consensus bugs found during the Interop
that doesn't pick up the test. Doesn't pick up by the test. We passed all the tests before.
So I think that's the biggest license we learned. Testing is really important.
Also, I forgot to say that we tested GVM at P2P as well as our client. And he fixed some bugs.
And it's now compatible. At least the stack that used for Interop is now compatible with
all other implementations like JavaScript, Python, and Rust.
I also want to use this moment to toss out a PSA. We're all using the same BLS library at the
moment, I believe. Yeah. So if anyone out there wants to write a BLS implementation, more implementations
is better. On the note of BLS implementations, the standardization efforts have been charging
forward. And we have some more reference implementations from those efforts. So hopefully within the
next one month or so, we should have what is the final specification for BLS, which is really a
major step forward. And that means that basically, then, that's the last hurdle in terms of specification
that's left. Also, moving on, we've had all these Interop events, but we need to now start transitioning
to more organic starting up of these events and allowing clients to properly sync with one another
we previously used scripts and files to start up these test nets. But to have more,
that's the way we allow validators to join into your network and transitioning into
proper test nets. So I would be interested to hear comments on how we can do this and what are
the challenges and what are the next steps in these regards.
Yeah, so I think a huge step forward from what we had at Interop would be testing out
our ETH1 integration. I think most of the clients have at least some form of it. But essentially,
this would be like having some ETH1 test net, ideally one that we kind of all could easily,
for example, produce ETH4 or spend up or spend down as we need. And then use that to kind of
test, okay, like you're saying here's a real world setting where it's like there's an ETH1
network, we then have this ETH2 deployment, how can we actually have validators join and leave,
but mainly join. Yeah. I think it's time for specialization. I think we're going to see like
all the clients at this point. Now that we know we can talk and we know like we have a baseline,
we're going to see everybody kind of splitting down, isolating and like going down, basically
challenging, you know, their languages and their respective implementations to whatever it is that
like their original goal was set out to be. I think that's probably what we'll see like
happen the next six months. For us as well, the very next milestone is running test nets connected
to ETH1. And for this, we've been following the lead of Prism and we have been publishing the
positive contract on the goal network. And I expect that we will have some interoperability
with, they will be able to use ours contract and you'll be able to use theirs and so on.
And there have been some talks in the, here, the last few days. What do the clients agree that
it would be beneficial if we set up a shared organization on GitHub where everybody has
commit rights and where we can work on and improve these scripts that allow each developer to launch
test nets on their own computer, on their own environment. So I see two directions. One is
public facing test nets running on ETH1 and then the ability for everyone to just make quick
walk-off setups for quick validation. >> Yeah. We really enjoy using Gorley. I think Gorley is
becoming a lot more of a de facto standard as well for ETH1 devs to test out smart contracts
and it's been really nice to try out deposits. Another big effort is the API standardization
effort that will come over the coming months. So there's a lot of talk about not having people
use the CLI to stake to run validators. Can we have a standardized API that allows people to
build things, interesting things like wallet, explorers, other things that allow you to interact
with the chain. And that will be a really critical effort over the coming months as well.
>> On the note of sharing deposit contracts, do you think it's worth then having one
centralized deposit contract on Gorley or similar? >> Well, for the world of these test nets,
it makes a lot of sense to restart them frequently and then nothing prevents you from having
multiple deposit contracts being acted. For the same time, basically the client only needs to
specify the address of the deposit contract that you'll be using. >> Just in terms of the shared
deposit contract, I think something that would be nice to would be a common onboarding process
for validators. I think the ETH was maybe considering about jumping on that. So yeah, it would be
nice if we don't all have to build a million different little validator onboarding things
than to be superseded by an official one coming up. >> We also probably want to test these
big and chain start for many times because it could be a huge point of failure. I mean,
the kicking off from ETH1, chain to the big and chain. So that's probably
worth to focus on as well. >> Definitely. We don't want to find that out in production.
On that topic, I think it would also be worth discussing what are the
valid criteria or how would we decide that we are ready to do this mainnet launch. So I agree
one of them should be that we've had launches based off ETH1 and these starts. But how do we
actually decide that this is the finalised version, both in terms of we can specify minimum ETH
deposits and that kind of thing. But also more in terms of what do we require of clients to be
able to participate in these networks and how do we say that this client should or shouldn't
participate. I mean, obviously it's not going to be some definitive thing. But what is a good
signal for deciding that a client is ready for participating in a mainnet launch?
>> I mean, yeah, that's obviously a big question. At a high level, right? I would expect we want
this to be actually fairly community driven, probably highly directed by the client developers
themselves. Obviously, there's things like uptime and performance and stuff, right? So,
for example, if we end up with a ton of early validators, we all want clients to be able to
handle that many validators. I know, for example, Trinity can't scale to the theoretical max right
now. We just don't have the performance. We'll get there, but we're not there yet.
So these types of things are really important qualifications.
At a certain point, it's hard to say, are you ready? You can always defer and do more testing.
So at a certain point, you just have to say, well, these are all sounding really negative.
I was going to say jump off the cliff or something. But yeah, hopefully we know when we see it,
and we're like, okay, we all feel good. Here we go.
Yeah, I agree. Sorry. There should be some -- we should start testing with some -- the
parameters that affect the performance of the network. We should start validating that
each of the clients is ready for this. But our own roadmap is also built around the need for
performing security audit on our code. And this is a pretty complicated thing to plan out because
it requires you to freeze a lot of the code. So we are
currently creating a plan that would allow us to create sort of a pipeline for
small and small components that will go through audit and then bigger and bigger parts until
we are ready to launch. Yeah, I was going to comment along the same lines. I mean,
in this network, you can't prevent anyone from saying I'm a validator and being part of the
network, and that's a whole point. So it requires client teams need to take responsibility
on the one hand. And so I think exactly right audits are going to be important. One of the very
striking differences between Ethereum 2 and Ethereum 1 is that in ETH 2, we need to do online
signing. You have to have your key available to sign in real time, which is something that all
the ETH 1 clients and nodes have moved away from over the years because it is really hard to do
it securely. So that's going to be a critical point where we need to focus audit and security
effort on that. And on the other hand, users need to be kind of wise as well because they have to
choose a client in which to run and to stake and so forth. And I think the best thing we can do
there is probably to have some joint benchmark suite or some is all about information, right,
making it consistent and so people can compare and contrast and understand which is a client
that meets their needs. But yeah, I definitely like to see a diversity. I think it would be a
shame if the network were dominated by one client, more than 50% on one client would be a pity.
I guess another point of point of point is formally verified the safety and livenies of the beacon
chain. So as you know, in the paper wise, the paper that proved these two properties on that
the abstract model of the beacon chain, but reality is the implementation has quite a lot
of the optimization and also slightly different definalization rules. So just make sure that those
differences doesn't actually break the safety and livenies. So yeah, that's our actually call.
In our end, you wanted to finish the form verification before others are actually ready to release.
Yeah, and the safety of all our clients relies on this assumption that someone's going to
slash bad people. I don't know anyone that's got a slash a working that can efficiently run,
they can efficiently cover the distance that we need. And it's still in research as to, you know,
how exactly can we, how can we store all of the previous votes and efficiently search them?
So we're definitely going to need slashes out there. And I think they're going to have to have
some degree of review and guarantee that, you know, they're watching and they'll get you.
Adding on to that quickly, we also need like slashing protection, right? So like in terms of
like infrastructure providers or people that are, they just don't want some sort of crazy situation
with their infrared to cause them to double propose or double sign. So that's also something I need.
So he built in and users will be asking for that. I totally agree with everything that's been said
and we want just to add that we might probably need some more QA stuff like fuzzing. We want to do
cross client fuzzing to find three key consensus breaks that could not be probably found,
could not be probably found during test net runs. And also we need to expose basic interface to
change data to build the even primitive block explorers around that and to get some network
monitors to understand what is going on. So yeah, that's my point.
Another fun thing leading up to production would be in some device test nets. So in a
cosmos community they've done some of those with game mistakes. It'd be fun if we do the same thing,
get together, a prize pool. And the idea is we have a test net, public test net,
anyone can come and go and then try to keep the test net alive.
I think the other thing would be like actually talking into validators or potential validators
and getting their input in a product feedback type setting. I think we were all very focused on
the spec and engineering and making really nice, sexy clients. But definitely it's for phase zero
who are the users of these things, validators. So talking to operators of validation pools and
not just pools, but validators in general. And seeing how that process unfolds.
Sorry one more. I think we need some interest from external,
non-client developer team UI people. So I think a lot of the client developers where systems
programmers and the idea of choosing a color makes us sweat. So it'd be great to have,
and we don't, I think at the moment, have maybe a few people that are front-end devs that are
interested in building UIs for this. And it'd be great to have these things as a common good that
lives outside of the client teams that guests the love that they deserve.
And on top of that, I think it's very important for the general validator experiences to not only
just help them with the generating of the clients, but what happens when validators get slashed?
How do we notify them of this? Or when there's major chain consensus, how do you, if your clients
not updating, or there's something, there's some fundamental issue, how do we notify clients of
these problems? And we could probably have some central solution which sends you an email or
something, but having people register their validators with such a thing as a kind of scary
concept from a privacy standpoint. So how can we enable these kinds of things which I think are
also very important for the community and to help validators understand what their clients doing
and how they can stay on top of things? Cool. Well, with that, I think, because we were
heading into the final minutes here, I'd like to open the floor to questions for anyone who'd like
to talk about anything related to the media future of E3.0.
I'm somewhat forwarding this question from Philippe Castingay from Horizon Games and the Fairwind
Ponzi Scheme Revelation. My name's John Marlin. I do security audits, so I'm not adaptive, but
I know a lot of us are more contracts. And his question is about the migration process
and if there are plans for doing any migration testing for DAPs moving to the E3.0.0.
Mainnet.
Yeah, no, definitely. So the migration from ETH1 to ETH2 is clearly something that came up
in the discussions yesterday, too, and it's a very important thing. And clearly a pain point
for the community. I think it's something everyone is nervous about. We have this great community
within Ethereum 1. How can we transfer that as seamlessly as possible? We don't want bugs in
any of these scenarios. The challenge with answering this question is that right now
we have such flexibility in the space that is very hard to answer exactly what this is going to
look like. So it is some form of moving roots between ETH1 and ETH2 and we will have an execution
engine which allows ETH1 to run very similarly to how it does right now. And that will be
very well tested for these kinds of purposes. But I think the challenge here is we're trying
with these execution environments that allow us such flexibilities and so many possibilities.
We try to not lock ourselves down to committing to saying exactly this is how it's going to work
right now because that starts closing down the design space for us and could ultimately end up
in a worse product. So the answer to that is yes, it will be tested. There will be some migration
path exactly what that looks like. I can't specify right now but that will definitely exist and is
vital for the continuation of ETH3 and ETH2.0.
And just add on to that, like concretely there's definitely an intention to essentially move ETH1
into the new ETH2 infrastructure in a way that you wouldn't have to migrate your DAP and it would
just continue to run. Not quite seamlessly. There will be some sort of metadata updates of like a
new network, new chain, that sort of thing. But in terms of like you wouldn't have to rewrite your
DAP or do these things. That being said, there will be an opt-in upgrade path to go to perhaps
this new type of EVME that Carl was alluding to which you'd get a lot of honestly great improvements
on top of all we have today. So yeah, keep an eye out.
And I think a lot of this ties into what Greg's presentation was on earlier on how do we making
connections and building common tooling between these frameworks. And it's very important to have
these intermediate tools between the two chains. It's totally having an easy path for upgrades is
definitely important and it will be there. Something else worth considering too is that
if you've just gone from this pocket calculated to this multi-core,
thousand times faster machine, perhaps a refactor is going to be important for a lot of the DAPs.
Like I'm not saying that you're going to have to refactor but you've got a whole new space to
play in now. And a refactor might be what you end up doing because it will be better for your
customers or not customers people that are using your thing opting in without any control from you.
The answer, where's the conversation happening? Where do you guys like interact with the DAP
dev community so they can ask those questions online? Hey, I can speak on behalf of that a little
bit. We're a little bit early still. That's like phase two. And to be quite frank, a lot of the
confusion around this is because some of the, as Carl explains, the design space is so open,
but it makes it also super complicated. A lot of people have to rethink the way this is.
How long do you take most developers to understand the EVM? Like two years before people are fully
understood. It's going to take some time to understand these new concepts. And once that happens,
you'll see a lot better. I don't think it's immediate to fully discuss with them. I think
the first priority is just talking with tooling teams to understand how we can better help them
and concurrently going with the DAP developers. Yeah, the quilt team deserves a plug here too.
They're building a simulator so that you can build EEs or tests on top of EEs without needing
all of the chain infrastructure. You can just start a process and start testing. So I think
this is something that's going to really enable DAP developers to get involved because it's a bit
a bit low level at the moment, I think, for them. But it's opening up to them.
Hey. So we were at Interop2 with WIPLOCK and we're very grateful. I think it was fun to work

which is, do you have a Docker image? Okay, cool. And wait, do you have a Docker image as well?
Okay. All right. So if we can help in any way, we're here to help. Right.
Do you have just give us credits and fun to that? So please involve us. We'll be happy to help.
A couple of you probably know, like, some of the ETH1 core Devs, but usually a lot of them are

want them to like try to look at, like maybe each of you, it's like what is it that you would

Sync strategies. So we're running out of time. So can we use this as like sort of a wrapping up

just a single line. So working on Trinity, we actually have a focus of both ETH1 and ETH2.
So I actually feel like I've been exposed a lot to a lot of the ETH1 efforts and ongoing

really just tackle the same questions. Like a big one that comes to mind is like state management

in ETH2 where like that's not going to be a problem. And yeah, like a lot of there's a lot of cool
ideas around like stateless clients and things that again have application in both domains.
Madby, I think a good thing we can learn is what to and not do with in terms of governance.
What we have right now with ETH1.2 is ETH2.2. The research team I think leads a lot of the
decisions. And so there's sort of a central shelling point which exists much less in ETH1.0.
And the idea is that the research team wants to have less and less of this role. But how can we do
this in a manner that prevents deadlock and allows for continuous innovation? I think a lot of lessons
to be learned from ETH1.0 there. I'd be willing to take anything. I'll take any advice from any
of the people that have been building ETH1 or blockchain or people like anything they've got,
bringing it here, looking for it. I think there's a lot of who can learn about

of the requests, these are areas where we can share the solutions. And kind of that grant,
I'm kind of excited about the possibility of ETH1 incorporating a lip-to-p support in some way.
This is something that's possible in the future.
Okay, probably, yeah, I'd like to take advice with network reputation systems,

Yeah, that's it. I'm actually mostly related to both ETH1 and ETH2. I'm actually both
care a lot about the backward capability issue. The thing is, currently,
probably all of your notes are in ETH1. We have a breaking change that creates a lot of conflicts.
I hope we can try to avoid the same situation on ETH2 by designing the execution engine

Just quickly before Carl wraps this up, I just wanted to just to announce that,
we're looking for a senior Rust developer. If you are a Rust developer and you want to work on ETH2,
come talk to us. Thank you.
Thanks everyone for attending that. Thank you to all of the clients represented here.
And I'm really excited to see the work that's going to happen. These incentivized test nets,
